Award.AwardTitle: Trilayer and Superlattice Half Metal Thin Films

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
There has been intense interest in silicon based spintronic materials, particularly half-metals, for room temperature device applications. In previous studies, half-metallicity has been predicted in thin films of Mn-doped Si. However, the Mn atoms need to occupy the energetically costly substitutional sites that require breaking of Si-Si bonds. This bond breaking process has been the major obstacle for achieving this class of materials that may take advantage of the mature Si technology. Very recently, the PI has predicted half-metallicity in two Mn/Si/Mn trilayers with Mn concentration at 0.5 monolayer and occupying the energetically favorable interstitial sites, and a 0.5 monolayer hole doping in the spacer layer. These exciting results suggest that half metallic Si-based trilayers and their related superlattices are within reach. This project combines theoretical and experimental efforts to design and realize such trilayer and superlattice pseudo-spin valves of silicon-based half-metal in thin film forms. The search for the ideal half-metallic trilayers and superlattices in ferromagnetic or antiferromagnetic phases, and modifications of existing algorithms to treat transport properties for proposed pseudo-spin valves will provide new knowledge concerning magnetism and electronic properties in layered structures. Doping in the Si spacer layer will be used to enhance the magnetic coupling between the two Mn layers. New algorithms of magnetic susceptibility will allow accurate determination of Curie temperature in any magnetic systems. Structural, magnetic, and magneto-transport measurements will be performed in order to characterize the fabricated structures and compare their properties with theoretical predictions. The use of silicon-based materials would enable rapid development of technological applications for spintronic devices. The synergy of the theoretical and experimental efforts is expected to facilitate the optimal design and fabrication of these novel devices.

Broader Impacts:
The proposed pseudo-spin valves are expected to exhibit new and intriguing half-metallic properties, which are highly relevant for the development of novel spintronic devices, such as sensors, switches, magnetic memory, and logic devices. Furthermore, new understandings will be gained on: (i) how can the hole doping between two layers of transition metal elements cause the half metallicity and couple the magnetic moments between Mn layers in the trilayers and superlattices? (ii) unique new knowledge about manipulating growth parameters to obtain samples of Si-based trilayer and superlattice pseudo-spin valves with predicted properties by the synthesis method. These advancements will significantly facilitate future developments of spintronic devices. The PIs will actively recruit underrepresented minority students to work with them. They have collaborations with research groups in the US, as well as in Sweden, Germany, China, Spain and Turkey. Graduate students will have the opportunity to interact with leading researchers in the field nationally, as well as internationally. The PIs also strive to integrate research with educational and outreach activities to enhance the learning experience of students from junior high school through graduate school.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigates a special type of magnetic materials known as half-metals in the thin film form. Such nanomaterials are expected to behave like a metal in one of the spin channels and a semiconductor in another. They are highly relevant for the development of novel spintronic devices, such as sensors, switches, and magnetic memory and logic, utilizing the electron spin degree of freedom.

Intellectual Merit

We have designed a novel type of half-metals based on hole-doped Mn/Si/Mn trilayers (Fig. 1). The Mn atoms occupy spaces in-between the atoms in the Si crystal lattice, known as interstitial sites. As a result, the doping process does not break any Si-Si bonds, if Mn has to replace a Si atom, which lowers the barrier for doping. In order to have current flow in the direction perpendicular to the doping layers of Mn atoms for device operations, we show that the doping of Al and Ga, respectively, in the Si region between the Mn layers also result in half-metallic properties in the doped trilayers. The band gaps of these trilayers have been improved to 0.133eV and 0.104 eV for the Al and Ga cases, respectively, which are substantially larger than thermal fluctuations at room temperature.

For device applications using half-metals, the stability and the strength of the spin-orbit interaction must be addressed. We have investigated the stability issue by calculating the acoustic vibrations to show that the frequencies are positive for stable half metals. Fig. 2 shows the phonon spectra of MnSi (unstable) and LiMnSi at the lattice constant of 6.59A (stable). To ensure that the spin-orbit interaction can be neglected, we have proposed a set of criteria based on accurate first-principles calculations.

In the literature, half-Heusler alloys are predicted to show their half metallic properties at lattice constants larger than the optimized values. It has been argued that devices based on them can be made in the thin film form. However, the strain in the material may lead to a short life-time for such devices. We have designed an alloy, LiCrS, exhibiting half metallic properties at its optimized lattice constant, a negligible spin-orbit effect, and the largest magnetic moment possible for Cr. This opens up possibilities of realizing spintronic devices made of this alloy in crystalline forms with long life-times.

Our findings provide essential information on the compositions of half-metallic hole-doped Mn/Si/Mn trilayers, raise the standards for future half-metal designs, including the stability issue, the effect of the spin-orbit interaction, and provide the design of a new long life-time half-Heusler alloy. 

Additionally, spin-dependent electrical transport properties have been investigated in thin-film based artificial magnetic skyrmion lattices and have provided key evidence for the realization of a stable ground state at room temperature (Fig. 3). Ionic transport across metal/oxide interfaces has been directly probed using an interface-sensitive exchange bias phenomenon, in conjunction with depth-resolved characterizations by neutron and x-ray. A highly effective magnetoelectric coupling, moderated by voltage-driven oxygen migration, is observed to extend beyond the metal/oxide interface region.

This project has so far led to 20 publications in top journals in the field, one book, one book chapter, and two patent applications. Results from this award have been presented in over 40 invited talks, including some at major international conferences in the field, and over 20 contributed conference presentations.

 

Broader impacts

Findings from this project have potentially important technological impacts and set high standards for future designs of half metals. We have designed the following systems: (1) Hole-doped trilayers provide a new kind of Si-based half-metals. The Mn atoms in the trilayers occupy interstitial sites. The doping barrier is lower than that in substitutional doping since there is no need to break any bonds to achieve doping. (2) A half-Heusler alloy, LiCrS, is suitable for fabrication of spintronic devices with long life-times and large magnetic moments. We raise the standards for designing new half metals by including stability and effects of the spin-orbit interaction. Results on magnetic vortices, artificial skyrmions and ionic transport are highly relevant for a host of novel nanomagnetic applications, such as low power magnetic memory and logic devices and spin-torque oscillators. Two patent applications have been filed on room temperature magnetic skyrmions and tetrataenite films.

This project has contributed to the education and training of several graduate and undergraduate students, and led to three Ph.D. theses. UCD graduate students carried out experiments at the National Institute of Standards and Technology, Advanced Light Source, Los Alamos National Laboratory, Seagate, and other facilities. They presented their work at many conferences, including delivering several invited talks on PI’s behalf. They received a number of distinctions as well, including a Margaret Burbidge Award for Best Experimental Research at the 2013 APS Far West Annual Meeting, a National Research Council Postdoctoral Fellowship, and a Livermore Graduate Scholarship.
